experiences.introduction: Enjoy a day immersing in Sha Ha Beachâ€™s watersports with help from Ah Kwok, which offers equipment you can use for canoeing, kayaking, windsurfing, and more.
experiences.name: Ah Kwok (Sha Ha)

experiences.introduction: Make your excursion to Stanley Main Beach more fun by engaging in watersports offered by Aquabound. Here, you can receive professional instructions in windsurfing, kayaking, wakeboarding, and more.
experiences.name: Aquabound (Stanley)

experiences.introduction: If youâ€™re ready to learn kiteboarding, enrol at Hong Kong Kiteboarding School. The school provides formal International Kiteboarding Organization (IKO) lessons and kite repair courses.
experiences.name: HK Kiteboarding School

experiences.introduction: If youâ€™re in Tai Long Wan (Big Wave Bay) and you need waterboards, wetsuit, and other watersports equipment, rent them from Ho Lok Store, one of the surf shops by the beach.
experiences.name: Ho Lok Store (Big Wave Bay)

experiences.introduction: If youâ€™re into a more advanced kayaking experience, do it at Pak Lap Wan which is located in Sai Kung Country Parkâ€™s eastern reaches. Thereâ€™s a kayak equipment rental near this beach.
experiences.name: Pak Lap Wan

experiences.introduction: Rent a kayak from Sharon to explore the waters around Hoi Ha village. Surrounded by a marine park, this place is only a 20-minute ride from Sai Kung town centre. You can also snorkel around here.
experiences.name: Sharon (Hoi Ha)

experiences.introduction: Want to explore the depths but youâ€™re yet to learn how to dive? Enrol at Splash Hong Kong where certified trainers will guide you through confined water lessons and open water dives.
experiences.name: Splash Hong Kong

experiences.introduction: Wakeboard.com.hk is where you can have memorable wakeboarding and wakesurfing experiences. With a fleet of MasterCraft wakeboards, the company offers packages for companies, families, and schools.
experiences.name: Wakeboard.com.hk

experiences.introduction: One of the first companies to teach wakesurfing in Hong Kong, Wakesurfing HK can provide you with the best watersports equipment to let you enjoy this sport. The company is located in Tai Tam.
experiences.name: Wakesurfing HK

experiences.introduction: New to wakeboarding or speedboating? Get trained with WPS Wakeboard HK in Sai Kung. Intermediate and advanced participants can join, too. Wakeboard boat rental is also available.
experiences.name: WPS Wakeboard HK

experiences.introduction: Devilâ€™s Peak used to be an essential passage to Victoria Harbour in the 20th century. A 207-degree view of the harbour awaits you at the trenches. You can spot some historical remnants here.
experiences.name: Devil's Peak

experiences.introduction: Jardineâ€™s Lookout Hike proves that you donâ€™t have to hike far to enjoy a beautiful view of the city. This short trail allows you to appreciate a relaxing sunset view with little crowd.
experiences.name: Jardine's Lookout Hike

experiences.introduction: Lamma Island Hikeâ€™s trail will take you to Hung Shing Yeh Beach where you can enjoy the sun and the white sand. Move on to the islandâ€™s Family Trail and be rewarded with a splendid view.
experiences.name: Lamma Island Hike

experiences.introduction: If youâ€™re just starting to hike, consider Lion Rock. With a 495-metre climb, reaching the pinnacle is an achievement in itself because it is one of Hong Kongâ€™s highest peaks.
experiences.name: Lion Rock

experiences.introduction: Hike on a sunny day at Sharp Peak, one of the Sai Kung regionâ€™s highest points. Thereâ€™s no break in incline as you go straight up from the beach but the coastal views from atop are worth it
experiences.name: Sharp Peak

experiences.introduction: Although itâ€™s called Suicide Cliff, itâ€™s no place for tragedy. The viewpoints in this trail are very precarious so be careful! Snap your best pose here with Kowloon in the background.
experiences.name: Suicide Cliff

experiences.introduction: Sunset Peak hike has one of the best viewpoints for sunsets. Start by climbing the long set of stairs that leads to a trail and into the forest. Emerge to the hilltop and youâ€™ll reach the peak.
experiences.name: Sunset Peak

experiences.introduction: Taking The Peak hike will reward you with a photo op with Victoria Harbour and HK's skyscrapers as backdrops. The hike itself is easy and you'll even see children and the elderly along the trail.
experiences.name: The Peak

experiences.introduction: Test your limits at The Twinsâ€™ 4.8-kilometre trail â€”one of the most challenging hikes in Hong Kong. The 1,200-step climb to the peak will surely work your glutes and legs to the max!
experiences.name: The Twins

experiences.introduction: Hailed as the hardest hike in Hong Kong, West Dogâ€™s Teeth Ridge is an 850-metre incline wherein youâ€™ll have to boulder and scramble to reach the ridgeâ€™s end. At the end of this trail is Lantau Peak.
experiences.name: West Dogâ€™s Teeth Hike

collectionDetail.name: What a Racket!
collectionDetail.introduction: Weâ€™re serving top tier courts. Game, set, match!

experiences.introduction: Fancy some recreational activities with friends or family? Go to Choi Hung Road Sports Centre and book their facilities. Better yet, join the centreâ€™s monthly sports and recreation programmes.
experiences.name: Choi Hung Road Sports Centre

experiences.introduction: Flora Ho Sports Centre is an indoor sports centre located in the Centre for Sports and Exercise (CSE). Aside from a large hall for sports, Flora Ho has other multipurpose areas.
experiences.name: Flora Ho Sports Centre

experiences.introduction: With three all-glass courts, two of which are exhibition courts, Hong Kong Football Club has one of the best squash facilities in Asia. The club also offers memberships for other sports.
experiences.name: Hong Kong Football Club

experiences.introduction: If youâ€™re into playing squash, head to Hong Kong Squash Centre for practice. This centre aims to develop this sport in Hong Kong, safeguarding and maintaining the squash rules and regulations.
experiences.name: Hong Kong Squash Centre

experiences.introduction: Although Royal Hong Kong Yacht Club primarily caters to watersports, it hosts several squash leagues and tournaments for its members. The club's squash court can be booked for 45 minutes per session.
experiences.name: Royal Hong Kong Yacht Club

experiences.introduction: Whether you're new to squash or want to get back into it, consider honing your skills at Sheung Wan Sports Centre. It has 5 squash courts for practice. The centre is open 7 AM to 11 PM daily.
experiences.name: Sheung Wan Sports Centre

experiences.introduction: Boost your sprint speed, flexibility, and other attributes that you'll need for squash here at South China Athletic Association. It offers squash courses for all ages as well as private lessons.
experiences.name: South China Athletic Association

experiences.introduction: Sun Yat Sen Memorial Park Sports Centre offers opportunities for diverse recreational activities. Here, you will find facilities such as dance rooms, Child-Friendlyâ€™s game rooms, fitness rooms, and more.
experiences.name: Sun Yat Sen Memorial Park Sports Centre

experiences.introduction: Bring your friends or family for a weekend squash play at Tsing Yi Sports Centre. You can also participate in the centre's monthly recreational activities and sports events for the public.
experiences.name: Tsing Yi Sports Centre

experiences.introduction: Hone your tennis skills at Victoria Park Tennis Courts which has a 3,600-seater enclosed tennis arena. You can book one of the parkâ€™s 13 courts for your other recreational activities.
experiences.name: Victoria Park Tennis Courts

experiences.introduction: Located in Wan Chai, Hong Kong Tennis Centre features 17 courts wherein 3 are dedicated for singles only. Here, two practice courts are half the size of a standard tennis court.
experiences.name: Hong Kong Tennis Centre

experiences.introduction: Fancy playing tennis while receiving coaching and fitness training? Do it at HKTA Tennis Centre which is located in Kowloon Tsai Park. You can even rent a court here with floodlights.
experiences.name: HKTA Tennis Centre

experiences.introduction: Round up your friends and head to Bowen Road Tennis Courts for a series of friendly tennis plays. Located in Wan Chai, this place has four courts to choose from.
experiences.name: Bowen Road Tennis Courts

experiences.introduction: Managed by the LCSD, Shek Kip Mei Park Tennis Courts are known for their relative quietness and cleanliness. With barrier-free facilities, the park has a Braille directory floor plan and map.
experiences.name: Shek Kip Mei Park Tennis Courts

experiences.introduction: Yuen Wo Playground Tennis Courts are perfect for improving your tennis skills even at night. Open 7:00 AM to 11:00 PM daily, the 6 courts are equipped with floodlights.
experiences.name: Yuen Wo Playground Tennis Courts

experiences.introduction: Want to get started with fishing? Happy Fish Farm is a great place to do so! With an area of about 12, square feet, this manmade fishing pond will give you plenty of catches.
experiences.name: Happy Fish Farm

experiences.introduction: Sit back and relax as you wait for your fish catch in one of the sheltered rafts at Kau Sai Wan Fishing Wonderland. A full-day package here comes with fishing equipment, a crash course, and more.
experiences.name: Kau Sai Wan Fishing

experiences.introduction: A fun-filled holiday experience awaits you at Long Coast Seasports! From surfing and wake surfing to glamping and more, there are plenty of recreational activities to do here.
experiences.name: Long Coast Seasports

experiences.introduction: If you want to have a peaceful time fishing, Ma Wan Tai Pai Tsui Pier offers a secluded spot on Ma Wanâ€™s southern tip. This place might be a ghost town but you wonâ€™t run out of fishing spots here.
experiences.name: Ma Wan Tai Pai Tsui Pier

experiences.introduction: Plover Cove Reservoir is one of the popular go-to fishing spots in Hong Kong. Obtain a license first before fishing here. Keep in mind that reservoirs are open from September 1 to March 31 only!
experiences.name: Plover Cove Reservoir

experiences.introduction: Having fun does not have to hurt. Go to Ryze Trampoline Park and try its trampolines, jumping boards, and foam pits. Bounce off the walls and jump all you want without fear of hurting yourself!
experiences.name: Ryze Trampoline Park

experiences.introduction: Shek Pik Reservoir is where you can practise fishing without worrying about unpredictable water flow thatâ€™s common in other fishing spots. Try your luck catching carp or jewelfish here!
experiences.name: Shek Pik Reservoir

experiences.introduction: Siu Sai Wan Promenade is a waterfront where you can get your fishing fix without traveling too far from the city. A perfect bonding experience with your friends and family!
experiences.name: Siu Sai Wan Promenade

experiences.introduction: Choose your own adventure here at Superpark, a 45,-square foot facility for a variety of recreational activities and sports. It is divided into the Adventure Area, Game Arena, and Freestyle Hall.
experiences.name: Superpark

experiences.introduction: If youâ€™re interested in deep-sea fishing, Tailchasers has you covered. Make sure to come here before October so that youâ€™ll have plenty of opportunities to catch mahi-mahi, black marlins, and sailfishes.
experiences.name: Tailchasers

experiences.introduction: While Peng Chau is not ideal as a swimming destination, the sandy beaches around it are great spots for picnics or sunbathing. Make sure to snap some photos while you're there!
experiences.name: Peng Chau

experiences.introduction: Spend a day away from the city at Tai Long Wan, a four-beach secluded spot where you can swim, sunbathe, hike, and even surf. For an extra thrill, try cliff-jumping at the Sheung Luk Stream nearby.
experiences.name: Tai Long Wan

experiences.introduction: Cooldown and relax on Stanley Main Beach's sands after doing The Twins Hike.  The beach is used for a variety of water sports. You might even see dragon boating teams train here.
experiences.name: Stanley Main Beach

experiences.introduction: Although smaller than other beaches around Stanley Main Beach, St. Stephenâ€™s Beach is a good choice if you want a secluded and shaded getaway. Barbeque pits are also available for outdoor cooking.
experiences.name: St. Stephenâ€™s Beach

experiences.introduction: Since Repulse Bay Beach is one of HK's most accessible beaches, make sure to get here early so you won't catch the crowd later in the day. Even with the number of visitors, the beach remains clean.
experiences.name: Repulse Bay Beach

experiences.introduction: Deep Water Bay is more popular among the locals than tourists for its quieter setting, making it a preferable dwelling for a number of wealthy people and celebrities.
experiences.name: Deep Water Bay

experiences.introduction: Catch a glimpse of Hong Kong without the skyscrapers in Shek O Beach, a popular getaway for newcomers. With a sandy beach and clear waters, this place is an excellent chilling spot on a hot day.
experiences.name: Shek O Beach

experiences.introduction: If youâ€™re a surfer, you will love Big Wave Bayâ€™s consistent swells. This beach is the only one that Hong Kong recognises as a surf beach. Enjoy a nice view here while downing a couple of drinks.
experiences.name: Big Wave Bay Beach

experiences.introduction: On a hot day, consider immersing in Hap Mun Bay Beachâ€™s cool waters. This beachâ€™s water quality is among the cleanest in Hong Kong. The best part? Itâ€™s only a quick sampan ride from Sai Kung.
experiences.name: Hap Mun Bay Beach

experiences.introduction: Want to catch a nice sunset view by the beach? Consider going to Golden beach, a manmade wonder with sands imported from Hainan. If you don't feel like swimming, take a stroll at the nearby promenade.
experiences.name: Golden Beach

experiences.introduction: The gentle waves and temperate waters of Clearwater Bay are perfect for chilling on a lazy afternoon. A stretch of rocky coast separates the more-secluded First Beach from the Second Beach.
experiences.name: Clearwater Bay (First & Second) Beaches

experiences.introduction: With crystal-clear waters and white sand, Long Ke Wan might as well be Hong Kongâ€™s Maldives. Even so, facilities are limited so bring your own food, water, and other necessities when going there.
experiences.name: Long Ke Wan

experiences.introduction: Soft, white sand awaits you by the Pui O Beach, making it a perfect weekend spot for families with children. Its gentle waves are ideal for novice surfers. Rent a cottage here and enjoy the view.
experiences.name: Pui O Beach

experiences.introduction: If youâ€™re visiting Cheung Sha, drop by its beaches. The Lower Beach is busier with cafes and recreational activities. The Upper Beach has no restaurant, but itâ€™s a good place to escape the crowd.
experiences.name: Upper and Lower Cheung Sha Beaches

experiences.introduction: A family favourite, Silvermine Bay Beach's waters are ideal for boogie boarding, swimming, and kayaking. It's even surrounded by lush mountains and white sand, perfect for chilling on a hot day.
experiences.name: Silvermine Bay Beach

experiences.introduction: Escape the city's hustle and bustle by travelling to Hung Shing Yeh Beach which is located a ferry away on Lamma Island. Food and drinks are conveniently nearby, so just bring yourself and relax.
experiences.name: Hung Shing Yeh Beach

experiences.introduction: Backed by a forest, Lo So Shing Beach is your getaway on a weekday when you could more likely have the place to yourself. Even so, there are vendors to buy sunscreen, water, and other basics from.
experiences.name: Lo So Shing Beach

experiences.introduction: A beach getaway with less crowd? Consider going to Tung Wan Beach on Ma Wan Island. Dip your toes into the white sands and the clear water. The beach is also popular for prenuptial photoshoots.
experiences.name: Tung Wan Beach

experiences.introduction: Whether youâ€™re into windsurfing or kayaking, be sure to visit Kwun Yam Beach. This place has plenty of recreations to keep you occupied, from cafes to water sports equipment rental and more.
experiences.name: Kwun Yam Beach

experiences.introduction: Hidden by trees and tucked off the road, Chung Hom Kok Beach might be tricky to find, but worth it. This quaint beach is a lot quieter compared to others nearby, so you can enjoy a peaceful stay here.
experiences.name: Chung Hom Kok Beach

experiences.introduction: Fancy some recreational activities with friends or family? Go to Choi Hung Road Sports Centre and book their facilities. Better yet, join the centreâ€™s monthly sports and recreation programmes.
experiences.name: Choi Hung Road Sports Centre

experiences.introduction: Flora Ho Sports Centre is an indoor sports centre located in the Centre for Sports and Exercise (CSE). Aside from a large hall for sports, Flora Ho has other multipurpose areas.
experiences.name: Flora Ho Sports Centre

experiences.introduction: With three all-glass courts, two of which are exhibition courts, Hong Kong Football Club has one of the best squash facilities in Asia. The club also offers memberships for other sports.
experiences.name: Hong Kong Football Club

experiences.introduction: If youâ€™re into playing squash, head to Hong Kong Squash Centre for practice. This centre aims to develop this sport in Hong Kong, safeguarding and maintaining the squash rules and regulations.
experiences.name: Hong Kong Squash Centre

experiences.introduction: Although Royal Hong Kong Yacht Club primarily caters to watersports, it hosts several squash leagues and tournaments for its members. The club's squash court can be booked for 45 minutes per session.
experiences.name: Royal Hong Kong Yacht Club

experiences.introduction: Whether you're new to squash or want to get back into it, consider honing your skills at Sheung Wan Sports Centre. It has 5 squash courts for practice. The centre is open 7 AM to 11 PM daily.
experiences.name: Sheung Wan Sports Centre

experiences.introduction: Boost your sprint speed, flexibility, and other attributes that you'll need for squash here at South China Athletic Association. It offers squash courses for all ages as well as private lessons.
experiences.name: South China Athletic Association

experiences.name: Tsing Yi Sports Centre

experiences.introduction: IKIGAIâ€™s uniquely designed space and creative curation of classes invites you to discover your reason for being with a humble, authentic and encouraging voice.
experiences.name: Ikigai

experiences.introduction: Make your excursion to Stanley Main Beach more fun by engaging in watersports offered by Aquabound. Here, you can receive professional instructions in windsurfing, kayaking, wakeboarding, and more.
experiences.name: Aquabound (Stanley)

experiences.introduction: Wakeboard.com.hk is where you can have memorable wakeboarding and wakesurfing experiences. With a fleet of MasterCraft wakeboards, the company offers packages for companies, families, and schools.
experiences.name: Wakeboard.com.hk

experiences.name: Happy Fish Farm

experiences.introduction: Sit back and relax as you wait for your fish catch in one of the sheltered rafts at Kau Sai Wan Fishing Wonderland. A full-day package here comes with fishing equipment, a crash course, and more.
experiences.name: Kau Sai Wan Fishing

experiences.introduction: If you want to have a peaceful time fishing, Ma Wan Tai Pai Tsui Pier offers a secluded spot on Ma Wanâ€™s southern tip. This place might be a ghost town but you wonâ€™t run out of fishing spots here.
experiences.name: Ma Wan Tai Pai Tsui Pier

experiences.introduction: Plover Cove Reservoir is one of the popular go-to fishing spots in Hong Kong. Obtain a license first before fishing here. Keep in mind that reservoirs are open from September 1 to March 31 only!
experiences.name: Plover Cove Reservoir

experiences.introduction: Shek Pik Reservoir is where you can practise fishing without worrying about unpredictable water flow thatâ€™s common in other fishing spots. Try your luck catching carp or jewelfish here!
experiences.name: Shek Pik Reservoir

experiences.introduction: Siu Sai Wan Promenade is a waterfront where you can get your fishing fix without traveling too far from the city. A perfect bonding experience with your friends and family!
experiences.name: Siu Sai Wan Promenade

experiences.introduction: If youâ€™re interested in deep-sea fishing, Tailchasers has you covered. Make sure to come here before October so that youâ€™ll have plenty of opportunities to catch mahi-mahi, black marlins, and sailfishes.
experiences.name: Tailchasers

experiences.introduction: Devilâ€™s Peak used to be an essential passage to Victoria Harbour in the 20th century. A 207-degree view of the harbour awaits you at the trenches. You can spot some historical remnants here.
experiences.name: Devil's Peak

experiences.introduction: Jardineâ€™s Lookout Hike proves that you donâ€™t have to hike far to enjoy a beautiful view of the city. This short trail allows you to appreciate a relaxing sunset view with little crowd.
experiences.name: Jardine's Lookout Hike

experiences.introduction: Lamma Island Hikeâ€™s trail will take you to Hung Shing Yeh Beach where you can enjoy the sun and the white sand. Move on to the islandâ€™s Family Trail and be rewarded with a splendid view.
experiences.name: Lamma Island Hike

experiences.introduction: If youâ€™re just starting to hike, consider Lion Rock. With a 495-metre climb, reaching the pinnacle is an achievement in itself because it is one of Hong Kongâ€™s highest peaks.
experiences.name: Lion Rock

experiences.introduction: While Peng Chau is not ideal as a swimming destination, the sandy beaches around it are great spots for picnics or sunbathing. Make sure to snap some photos while you're there!
experiences.name: Peng Chau

experiences.introduction: Roganic's strength lies in adapting to the local palate its array of delectable farm-to-table fine dishes. Created by Simon Rogan, he brings here the elements from his two-Michelin-starred L'Enclume.
experiences.name: Roganic

experiences.introduction: Hike on a sunny day at Sharp Peak, one of the Sai Kung regionâ€™s highest points. Thereâ€™s no break in incline as you go straight up from the beach but the coastal views from atop are worth it
experiences.name: Sharp Peak

experiences.introduction: Although itâ€™s called Suicide Cliff, itâ€™s no place for tragedy. The viewpoints in this trail are very precarious so be careful! Snap your best pose here with Kowloon in the background.
experiences.name: Suicide Cliff

experiences.introduction: Sunset Peak hike has one of the best viewpoints for sunsets. Start by climbing the long set of stairs that leads to a trail and into the forest. Emerge to the hilltop and youâ€™ll reach the peak.
experiences.name: Sunset Peak

experiences.introduction: Spend a day away from the city at Tai Long Wan, a four-beach secluded spot where you can swim, sunbathe, hike, and even surf. For an extra thrill, try cliff-jumping at the Sheung Luk Stream nearby.
experiences.name: Tai Long Wan

experiences.introduction: Taking The Peak hike will reward you with a photo op with Victoria Harbour and HK's skyscrapers as backdrops. The hike itself is easy and you'll even see children and the elderly along the trail.
experiences.name: The Peak

experiences.introduction: Test your limits at The Twinsâ€™ 4.8-kilometre trail â€”one of the most challenging hikes in Hong Kong. The 1,200-step climb to the peak will surely work your glutes and legs to the max!
experiences.name: The Twins

experiences.introduction: Hailed as the hardest hike in Hong Kong, West Dogâ€™s Teeth Ridge is an 850-metre incline wherein youâ€™ll have to boulder and scramble to reach the ridgeâ€™s end. At the end of this trail is Lantau Peak.
experiences.name: West Dogâ€™s Teeth Hike

experiences.introduction: Dragonâ€™s Back offers a beginner-friendly hike with not-so-hilly and easy access to some of the most Insta-worthy views. End your hike by Shek O Villageâ€™s beach.
experiences.name: Dragon's back

experiences.introduction: Hone your tennis skills at Victoria Park Tennis Courts which has a 3,600-seater enclosed tennis arena. You can book one of the parkâ€™s 13 courts for your other recreational activities.
experiences.name: Victoria Park Tennis Courts

experiences.introduction: Located in Wan Chai, Hong Kong Tennis Centre features 17 courts wherein 3 are dedicated for singles only. Here, two practice courts are half the size of a standard tennis court.
experiences.name: Hong Kong Tennis Centre

experiences.introduction: Fancy playing tennis while receiving coaching and fitness training? Do it at HKTA Tennis Centre which is located in Kowloon Tsai Park. You can even rent a court here with floodlights.
experiences.name: HKTA Tennis Centre

experiences.introduction: Round up your friends and head to Bowen Road Tennis Courts for a series of friendly tennis plays. Located in Wan Chai, this place has four courts to choose from.
experiences.name: Bowen Road Tennis Courts

experiences.introduction: Managed by the LCSD, Shek Kip Mei Park Tennis Courts are known for their relative quietness and cleanliness. With barrier-free facilities, the park has a Braille directory floor plan and map.
experiences.name: Shek Kip Mei Park Tennis Courts

experiences.introduction: Yuen Wo Playground Tennis Courts are perfect for improving your tennis skills even at night. Open 7:00 AM to 11:00 PM daily, the 6 courts are equipped with floodlights.
experiences.name: Yuen Wo Playground Tennis Courts

experiences.introduction: Spend a day away from the city at Tai Long Wan, a four-beach secluded spot where you can swim, sunbathe, hike, and even surf. For an extra thrill, try cliff-jumping at the Sheung Luk Stream nearby.
experiences.name: Tai Long Wan

experiences.introduction: Since Repulse Bay Beach is one of HK's most accessible beaches, make sure to get here early so you won't catch the crowd later in the day. Even with the number of visitors, the beach remains clean.
experiences.name: Repulse Bay Beach

experiences.introduction: Catch a glimpse of Hong Kong without the skyscrapers in Shek O Beach, a popular getaway for newcomers. With a sandy beach and clear waters, this place is an excellent chilling spot on a hot day.
experiences.name: Shek O Beach

experiences.introduction: With crystal-clear waters and white sand, Long Ke Wan might as well be Hong Kongâ€™s Maldives. Even so, facilities are limited so bring your own food, water, and other necessities when going there.
experiences.name: Long Ke Wan

experiences.introduction: Escape the city's hustle and bustle by travelling to Hung Shing Yeh Beach which is located a ferry away on Lamma Island. Food and drinks are conveniently nearby, so just bring yourself and relax.
experiences.name: Hung Shing Yeh Beach

experiences.introduction: Hidden by trees and tucked off the road, Chung Hom Kok Beach might be tricky to find, but worth it. This quaint beach is a lot quieter compared to others nearby, so you can enjoy a peaceful stay here.
experiences.name: Chung Hom Kok Beach
